nodes.text: Economists' empirical estimates and widely used IAMs (notably DICE) severely underestimate economic damages from climate change and are unfit for assessing climate risk or informing policy
The empirical economics literature produces trivial estimates of climate damages because of multiple methodological errors
Representative numeric estimates cited: DICE quadratic damage yields 2.1% loss at 3C and 7.9% at 6C; IPCC scatter contains many small-impact estimates
Economists commonly neglect climate tipping points and misrepresent scientific findings on their timing and impacts

Scientific literature (Lenton et al. and follow-ups) identifies multiple tipping elements likely triggerable this century and warns of tipping cascades; Nordhaus mischaracterised those findings and omitted tipping points from DICE damage functions
Many economic studies assume sectors not directly exposed to weather are insulated from climate impacts, omitting most of the economy
Nordhaus classified roughly 87% of US output as 'negligible effect' (indoor/controlled sectors); this exclusion logic appears in IPCC economics chapter and underpins enumerative studies
Economists often use spatial cross-sectional relationships between current temperature and income as a proxy for future climate-change impacts, which is methodologically flawed

Empirical support is weak: spatial fits explain little variance, ignore trade and historical adaptation, and cannot capture new extremes, wet-bulb lethal thresholds, or tipping-mediated systemic changes

DICE model structure: Ramsey growth backbone (representative agent, Cobb-Douglas production, exogenous TFP and labor), quadratic damage function D(T)=aT^2, abatement cost formulation, and optimization over consumption and mitigation

Because of its assumptions (functional forms, full employment, exogenous productivity, saddle-path equilibrium), DICE is structurally incapable of producing an economic collapse solution; even extreme damages lead to corner solutions, full mitigation, or eventual recovery

Sensitivity experiments: raising damage coefficient produces immediate maximal mitigation, dramatic falls in consumption and capital-output ratios, possible infeasible solution only when damages exceed a very high threshold (~98% of GDP); otherwise DICE recovers over centuries

Conclusion: Given methodological flaws in empirical damage estimates and structural limits of DICE and similar IAMs, these estimates and calibrated models should not be used to evaluate climate risks or set policy

Post-2014 studies sometimes report larger damages but often still extrapolate past spatial or time-series relationships and/or retain the weather-exposed-sector assumption, so they do not resolve core flaws
